job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Great opportunity to work in an educational environment filled with creative staff, students, and faculty and constant dialogue centered around critical thinking. Access to facilites and take am undergraduate course or two. 

Most students and faculty are a joy to interact with.
cons:
The upper level administration and management team is disconnected from the times & economy in which we live and the needs of the staff, faculty and students. Staff are not paid a living wage for one of the more expensive areas to live in the U.S. Job creep is a HUGE problem at this school. Rather than hire the necessary staff needed to fulfill the needs of the student & faculty, CCA chooses to stuff job positions with responsibilities that would logically and practically need at least one other person to fulfill.  

Admin policies directly curb and and adversely effect faculty abilities to teach. Faculty are not paid well and their concerns are not considered when upper management & admin execute new policies. 

The school is marketed as being for the students but the again the higher ups do not heed student concerns and each new remodel of the school each year takes more space from students and classes.  

The upper management and administration no longer practice transparency when making decisions that effect to workflow or environment of staff, faculty, and students.

review_title: Great school, but losing great employees
job_title: Full-time Advisor in San Francisco, CA
pros: Amazing colleagues and division to work with, very collaborative environment, being surrounded by art & design offers creative outlets, HR is working on creating more support for staff and faculty.
cons: Big disconnect between the decision-makers and the actual do-ers in the school. Like many, I have chosen to leave because the salary makes it extremely difficult to survive in the Bay Area on one job. There is no room for growth. The school is shifting very rapidly into a corporate mentality of running systems and processes, thus losing the creative history and background that the school was founded on.  Higher level administration, many coming with approaches from traditional schools are forcing their ideas into this non-traditional school, thus causing a lot of friction. There is a lack of transparency in where money is being spent- much of it on overpriced projects that could be completed in-house, and are usually shelved once they've been completed. The new branding of CCA is just ridiculous and offers and attitude that doesn't reflect the history of CCA at all. This is what happens when you pay outside companies to "figure out" what the school should be, instead of asking the backbone employees and students of the school what CCA actually is.

review_title: I want to, but I can't - a love story...
job_title: Assistant Director in San Francisco, CA
pros:
CCA is full of kind, hardworking, creative, and supportive employees.
It's a huge inspiration to work within non-profit education and support the creatives of the future. 
CCA values at their core, are spot on and the projection of the future campus is a great step towards mending a lot of issues for the employees and students (more importantly).

Management within my specific department grew a lot within the time I spent at CCA and fortunately for the better!
cons:
But it was too late..
The issue is that CCA can't keep up with itself. 

There's so many "different" teams and moving parts that communication is completely broken and all the said "hard working and bright employees" become exhausted and abused because they're stunted by the ones that are "stuck in their ways". There doesn't seem to be a great higher level management to build a structure towards an overall goal. It's almost always a battle to get something done.

If CCA wants to grow with the changes on the horizon, I'm hoping they're able to emulate the likeminded values in their employee support / overall happiness.

Put your money where your mouth is, I suppose.

job_title: Program Manager in Oakland, CA
pros: The Oakland campus is set in the lovely Rockridge neighborhood, one of the best in Oakland.
cons: Low salary, constant overwork, the massive turn over of the staff here - in most cases burning out workers within a year of starting. Run down facilities in OAK, lacking hygiene and heating in campus buildings. Too few offices and classrooms in the SF campus meaning there is nowhere to place yourself if you have to go the SF campus from OAK. Hard to make friends amongst the overstressed faculty and staff, no areas for staff socialization on campus. SF is a cold working environment that feels isolating -folks around you are constantly stressed and therefore come across as unfriendly. No living wage for the area, often recruiting staff from outside of the region to cover up this fact. This is one major cause of attrition. 1 year at CCA is the norm before folks resign. One department Marketing and Communications literally quit en masse recently, throwing the newly unveiled website into chaos. The staff are unionizing new for better pay and conditions, but they expect to be resisted at all turns. The opaque and hierarchical management structure that is often unresponsible to the suffering of the staff.

review_title: Such amazing potential, but money is mismanaged and key strategic decisions are never made
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Some great faculty members and degree programs and good connections to industry for students.

Modern, recently renovated campus building in SF and positive growth plans for the school.
cons:
CCA's tuition is absolutely obscene and a testament to pure greed when you consider students'  overall experience (e.g. campus housing located in run-down and scary neighborhoods like the Tenderloin amid ongoing stabbings and assaults, being hassled on campus by homeless drifters who have mental health challenges, students not being able to graduate on time due to too many course requirements which means that CCA gets to pocket more money during their fifth year, etc.)

President Stephen Beale couldn't make a simple decision even if his very life depended on it. Which has caused A LOT of smart plans to languish and never see the light of day (note the word "anguish" in "languish" - no accident there). Watching his continual indecisiveness was so...very...painful. Time for a change!

Many of the buildings around the SF and Oakland campus that CCA leases for its various administrative offices are terribly run-down, drafty, have black mold, pests, and smell worse than someone's grandmother's old musty clothes hanging in a Salvation Army.

review_title: Change is not easy - especially without strong leadership
job_title: Assistant Director in San Francisco, CA
pros:
CCA is a top notch arts institution where creative makers and thinkers come together to make art that matters. It's inspiring to work among some of the most talented artists, whether faculty, staff or students.
Casual and relaxed work environment.
cons:
There is a serious lack of leadership that is holding the college back and causing significant turn-over across many of the different departments across the college. Senior leadership seems largely unaware of the challenges and struggles of folks on the ground interfacing daily with students and faculty. 

Effective communication is almost non-existent at any level, causing a serious lack of coordination and engagement when it comes to executing initiatives or strategies. A strong silo effect in almost every area of the college further exasperates communication challenges and impedes cross-functional collaboration.

A real burn and churn environment for many front-line positions further causing disengagement and disfunction which ultimately impacts the students.

job_title: Staff Position in San Francisco, CA
pros:
- flexible hours
- good PTO time and other benefits
- tuition remission
- the warm fuzzy feeling of knowing you are working for an arts institution (even if you can't afford to live in the Bay Area while doing so)
cons:
- extremely low, embarrassingly low salary ("for the greater good of higher education!"). Just google the president's salary and you can see he is making half a million dollars while you make next to nothing for your very specialized skills.
- Super political, all about the system. People are very focused on the org chart. 
- Lots of people have been working there for 15-20 years and prefer to "do things as they always have done." Just waiting for their retirement.
- Projects take very long to come into fruition, slowly goes from enthusiasm to banging your head against a bureaucratic wall.
- Lots of people wanting to sit around rooms talking about big ideas, but only one person is doing the grunt work and getting the job done.
- Some offices are extremely understaffed, resulting in people doing the work of 3 people. Other offices have new people all the time, and you have no idea what everyone in the offices could possibly be doing all day.

job_title: Work-Study Administrative Assistant in Oakland, CA
pros: As a student, working at CCA is as local and practical as it gets. Work-study positions are a great way for students to make money and also become more familiar with having a job. I'd say students who also work while they are in college are more likely to find jobs after they graduate, and working for CCA is a great place to start. The employers are usually fun and friendly, understanding of your schoolwork, and are often artists themselves.
cons: As a student, I see many other work-study students sticking around CCA after they graduate. CCA is an excellent place to work as a student, but can be dangerous if you grow too comfortable and don't want to leave. Also, although work study has its advantages, it make be more beneficial to work outside of CCA while you are a student because otherwise your life may feel too centered around CCA - or even trapped at CCA. Working in the local community outside of the school can give you needed experience outside of CCA's bubble.
